questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with progressive pigmentation on palmar area X-ray spine shows calcification intervertebral disk. Patient urine turns black on standing. Which enzyme is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B : Homogentisate Oxidase

The enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Oxidase. And the disease called as Alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria

  • Autosomal Recessive Disorder is due to a deficiency of Homogentisic Acid Oxidase
  • First inborn error detected.
  • Belongs to Garrod’s Tetrad *Alkaptonuria, Albinism, Pentosuria, Cystinuria+

Biochemical defect

Homogentisate Oxidase deficiency leads to accumulation of Homogentisic Acid (Homogentisate) which polymerises to form Alkaptone bodies.

Clinical presentation

  • Normal Life till 3rd or 4th decade.
  • Urine Darkens on standing is the only manifestation in children.
  • In adults Ochronosis: Alkaptone Bodies in Interver tebral Disk, cartilage of nose, pinna etc.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • Alkalinization increase darkening of urine.
  • Benedicts test positive in urine because homogentisic acid is reducing agent.
  • Ferric Chloride test positive
  • Silver Nitrate Test
  • No Mental Retardation

Treatment

  • New Drug is Nitisinone [NTBC] which inhibit para Hydroxyl Phenyl Pyruvate hydroxylase which prevent the accumulation of homogentisic acid.
  • Symptomatic Treatment

Reference : Harper 31st e , page 706

choices.text: Enzyme Glycerol kinase plays an important role
Enzyme Glycerol 3 phosphate dehydrogenase plays an important role

questions.text: All of the following are true about synthesis of triacylglycerol in adipose tissue except:
questions.solution:
In Muscle and Adipose Tissue

  • Glycerol Kinase is absent in muscle and white adipose
  • Glycerol 3 Phosphate is formed from Dihydroxy Acetone Phosphate, an intermediate in Glycolysis.

questions.text: A Obese man want to reduce his weight. So he decided to fat free and carbohydrate diet but inspite of this he still increase his weight. So which of the following lipoproteins is found in serum?
questions.solution:
Inspite of fat free diet, excess Carbohydrates are converted to Acetyl CoA, which is converted to Fatty acid, esterified to produce Endogenous TGs. VLDL carry the endogenous TGs. So VLDL level rises.

Reference: Harper 30/e p140

choices.text: It is directly used by tissues for energy needs
It is formed due to increased activity of hor mone sensitive lipase
It is formed by increased activity of Lipoprotein Lipase

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding glycerol during fasting:
questions.solution:
In prolonged fasting Gluconeogenesis sets in and Glycerol liberated from stored TGs in adipose tissue by the action of hormone sensitive lipase.

Reference: Lippincott SAE page 461

questions.text: Which helps in the transport of chylomicrons from intestine to liver:
questions.solution:
• Transport of Chylomicron remnant to liver by Apo E
  • Transport of IDL or VLDL remnant to liver by Apo E
  • Transport of LDL to liver and Extrahepatic tissues by apo B100.

Ref: Harper 30/e p257

questions.text: A person regularly eating his/her meal daily. So his/her diet reach in acetyl CoA. So which is rarest product synthesize from this?
questions.solution:
• In well fed state fatty acid (Palmitic acid) synthesis is active
  • TCA cycle also takes place, Citrate and oxalosuccinate are intermediates in TCA Cycle
  • Oxalosuccinate is an intermediate in the reaction of Isocitrate Dehydrogenase of TCA Cycle
  • Acetoacetate, a primary ketone body is synthesized in fasting state.

Reference: Lippincott SAE page 460

questions.text: 40 year male want to reduce his weight, so he try to away from fatty food for several weeks. So which of the following lipid product is most deficient in him
questions.solution:
Prostaglandins are synthesize from arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid is synthesize from linoleic acid, an essential fatty acid obtained by humans from diet. So all other is synthesize but prostaglandin in decrease amounts.

Reference : Lippincott 7th e , page 213

questions.text: Which one of the following can be homo logous substitution for isoleucine in a protein in sequence?
questions.solution:
Conservative [Homologous] Substitution

  • One amino acid replaced by another amino acid of similar characteristics
  • Examples of homologous substitution is shown in the diagram given below.

Hydrophilic, Acidic = Asp, Glu

Hydrophilic, Basic= His, Arg, Lys

Polar, Uncharged = Ser,Thr.Gln,Asn

Hydrophobic =Ala,Phe,Leu,Ile,Val,Pro

Nonconservative (Nonhomologous) Substitution

  • One amino acid replaced by another amino acid of different

Ref: Vasudevan 7e page 24,25

questions.text: In which of the following structure polypeptide formation is occur:
questions.solution:
Primary Structure: It is the linear sequence of amino acid held together by peptide bonds in its peptide chains. Bond involved in primary structure is Peptide Bond, a type of covalent bond.

Secondary Structure

  • Configurational relationship between residues which are about 3–4 amino Acids apart in linear sequence.
  • The folding of short (3- to 30-residue), contiguous segments of polypeptide into geometrically ordered

Tertiary structure: The entire three-dimensional confor mation of a polypeptide is referred to as tertiary structure.

Quaternary structure: If more than one polypeptides aggregate to form one functional protein, the spatial relationship between the polypeptide subunits is referred to as Quaternary structure.

Reference: Harper 30/e p30

choices.text: Protein consisting of one polypeptide can have quaternary structure
The formation of disulfide bond in a protein requires that the two participating cysteine residues be adjacent to each other in the primary sequence of the protein
The formation of disulfide bond in a protein requires that the two participating cysteine residues be adjacent to each other in the primary sequence of the protein
The information required for the correct folding of a protei is contained in the specific sequence of amino acid along the polypeptide chain.

questions.text: Which one of the following about protein structure is correct:
questions.solution:
The information required for the correct folding of a protein is contained in the specific sequence of amino acid along the polypeptide chain.

  • Proteins with more than one polypeptide chain can only have quaternary structure.
  • The cysteine residues need not be adjacent for the formation of disulfide bond
  • The stability of quaternary structure is by noncovalent
  • Denaturation can be reversible

Reference: Harper 30/e p39, 40, 43, 44

choices.text: Can incorporate 2 atoms of oxygen in a substance
Can incorporate 1 atom of oxygen in a substance

questions.text: All of the following are true about oxygenases, except:
questions.solution:
• Oxygenases can be monooxygenase or dioxygenase
  • Monooxygenase incorporate 1 atom of Oxygen molecule to the substrate
  • Dioxygenase incorporate both the atoms of Oxygen molecule to the substrate
  • Phase 1 Xenobiotic reactions, hydroxylation, cata- lyzed mainly by members of a class of enzymes referred to as monooxygenases or cytochrome

Ref: Harper 30/e p118, 119

questions.text: Which of the following group contains only nonessential amino acid?
questions.solution:
• Group of amino acid that contain only essential amino acid is Branched chain amino acids (Leucine, Isoleucine, Valine)
  • Group of amino acid that contain only nonessential amino acid is Acidic Amino acids, Amide group containing amino acids, Imino acid, Simple amino acids

Reference: Harper 30/e p282

questions.text: Which of the following give Benedict test positive:
questions.solution:
Benedict’s test is a test for reducing substances in urine.

Carbohydrates that give positive Benedict’s test are:

  • Pentoses, Fructose, Glucose, Galactose
  • Reducing disaccharides like Lactose, Maltose, Isomaltose

Noncarbohydrates that give Benedict’s test positive are:

  • Homogentisic acid
  • Glucuronic acid
  • Salicylates
  • Ascorbic acid
  • Uric acid
  • Glutathione
  • Creatinine in very high amount

Nonreducing disaccharides, like Sucrose and Trehalose do not give positive Benedict’s test. Tests for reducing substances are Benedict’s test and Fehling’s test.

Reference : Varleys: Practical Clinical Biochemistry 4/e p110

questions.text: The type of enzyme inhibition in which Succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate is an example of:
questions.solution:
Examples of competitive inhibition

Statins inhibit HMG CoA Reductase.

Dicoumarol inhibit Vitamin K Epoxide.

Methotrexate inhibit Dihydrofolate Reductase

Succinyl Choline inhibit Acetyl Choline Esterase

Reference:- Harper 30/e p78

questions.text: Amino acid required for carboxylation of clotting factors by vitamin K ?
questions.solution:
<
  • Factor VII (Proconvertin or Serum Prothrombin conversion Accelerator, SPCA),
  • Factor IX (Antihemophilic factor or Christmas factor),
  • Factor X (Stuart Prower factor),
  • Protein C, Protein S,
  • Osteocalcin, Nephrocalcin
  • Product of gene gas 6

Reference: Harper 30/e p717

questions.text: After overnight fasting,level of glucose transporters are reduced in :
questions.solution:
GLUT-4 and Insulin

Glucose uptake into muscle and adipose tissue is controlled by insulin, which is secreted by the islet cells of the pancreas in response to an increased concentration of glucose in the portal blood.

In the fasting state, the glucose transporter of muscle and adipose tissue (GLUT-4) is in intracellular vesicles. An early response to insulin is the migration of these vesicles to the cell surface, where they fuse with the plasma membrane, exposing active glucose transporters. These insulin-sensitive tissues only take up glucose from the bloodstream to any significant extent in the presence of the hormone.

As insulin secretion falls in the fasting state, so that the receptors are internalized again, reducing glucose uptake.

Reference: Harper 29/e p158, 30/e p192

questions.text: Km changes and Vmax remains the same. What is the type of Enzyme inhibition?
questions.solution:
• Competitive inhibition—Km increases and Vmax remains the same
  • Noncompetitive inhibition—Km remains the same and Vmax decreases
  • Uncompetitive inhibition—Both Km and Vmax decrease

Reference: Harper 30/e p80

choices.text: Decreased utilization of amino acid from Gluconeogenesis
Leakage of amino acids from cells due to plasma membrane damage

questions.text: Increased alanine during prolonged fasting represents:
questions.solution:
During prolonged fasting, there is increased gluconeo genesis. Alanine provide by muscle is one of the important substance for strates for gluconeogenesis.

This is called Glucose Alanine Cycle or Cahill Cycle. So plasma level of Alanine rises in prolonged starvation.

Reference: Harper 30e page 191

questions.text: Lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency is due to which enzyme dysfunction?
questions.solution:
In Thiamine deficiency, PDH reaction is defective.

So Pyruvate is converted to lactic acid.

Causes of inhibition of PDH leading to lactic acidosis:

  • Inherited PDH deficiency
  • Thiamine deficiency
  • Alcoholics due to thiamine deficiency
  • Arsenite and Mercury

Reference: Harper 30/e p174

questions.text: Nonfunctional enzymes are all except:
questions.solution:
Functional enzymes

  • Enzymes which have specific function in the

Examples of functional enzymes

  • Coagulation Factors
  • Lipoprotein Lipase.

Nonfunctional enzymes

  • No specific function in the Serum
  • Comes out from the tissue as a result of normal wear and tear
  • There level is very low in the serum
  • But during tissue injury their level rises in the serum
  • Hence they help to diagnose the site of tissue
  • Examples of nonfunctional enzymes are LDH, Creatine Kinase, Alkaline Phosphatase.

(Ref: Vasudevan and Sreekumari 7/e p301)

questions.text: A patient of 9-month-old male child admitted with failure to thrive with high glutamine and uracil in urine. Hypoglycemia, high blood ammonia. Treatment was given. Again at 11 months admitted for failure to gain weight and became comatose. Intravenous glucose pine is give and child is recoverd. What is the enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
The feature given for the case are high glutamine and Uracil in urine:

High glutamine: Usually seen in hyperammonemia. Because Ammonia is the transport form of ammonia from brain and most other tissues. So in hyperammonemia Glutamine level is elevated.

Increased uracil in urine can be seen in Ornithine Transcarbamoylase defect because as OTC defective, carbamoyl phosphate in mitochondria spills to cytoplasm. Then it enters into Pyrimidine synthesis. Pyrimidine intermediates and pyrimidines can accumulate. Hence, Uracil in urine

Reference: Harper 30e/page 295

questions.text: Complex polysaccharides are converted to glucose and absorbed by the help of:
questions.solution:
The cells of brush border of intestine contain the enzyme, Sucrase, Maltase, Iso-maltase and lactase hydrolyse corresponding disaccharides to monosaccharides which are absorbed.

Reference: Harper 30/e p538

questions.text: LDH-5 level elevated in which cell injury:
questions.solution:
Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) is a tetrameric enzyme consisting of two monomer types:

H (for heart) and M (for muscle) that combine to yield five LDH isozymes:

HHHH (I1)

HHHM (I2)

HHMM (I3)

HMMM (I4), and MMMM (I5).

Tissue-specific expression of the H and M genes determines the relative proportions of each subunit in different tissues.

Isozyme LDH-I predominates in heart tissue, and isozyme LDH-5 in the liver.

Thus, tissue injury releases a characteristic pattern of LDH isozymes that can be separated by electrophoresis.

Reference: Harper 29/e p66

choices.text: Energy not used in Synthesis of argininosuccinate
Nitrogen of the urea comes from tyrosine and ammonia
Uses ATP during conversion of argininosucci nate to arginine

questions.text: Which of the following sentence about urea cycle is correct:
questions.solution:
<
  • ATP is required for CPS-I and Arginino Succinate Synthetase
  • Out of the 5 reactions, 3 reactions occur in So occur mainly in the cytoplasm.
  • Energy is used in Synthesis of argininosuccinate

Reference: Harper 30e page 291-292

questions.text: Facilitated transport of glucose that is insulin insensitive (non-dependent) takes place in:
questions.solution:
Insulin responsive Glucose transporters are

  • GLUT 4-Heart, Skeletal Muscle, Adipose tissue
  • GLUT 8-Testis, Blastocyst, Brain, Adipose tissue
  • GLUT 12-Heart, Prostate, White adipose tissue, mammary

Reference: Harper 30/e p191

questions.text: Proteins are linear polymers of amino acids. They fold into compact structures. Sometimes, these folded structures associate to form homo-or- heterodimers. Which one of the following refers to this associated form?
questions.solution:
strong>Primary Structure is the linear sequence of amino acid held together by peptide bonds in its peptide chains. Bond involved in primary structure is Peptide Bond, a type of covalent bond.

Secondary Structure

  • Configurational relationship between residues which are about 3–4 amino Acids apart in linear sequence.
  • The folding of short (3- to 30- residue), contiguous segments of polypeptide into geometrically ordered units
  • Bonds involved in the secondary structure are primarily noncovalent bonds like:
    • Hydrogen Bond (Most important Bond)
    • Hydrophobic Bond
    • Electrostatic Bond (Ionic Bond, Salt Bridges)
    • vander Waals

Tertiary structure: The entire three-dimensional conformation of a polypeptide is referred to as tertiary structure.

Quaternary structure: If more than one polypeptides aggregate to form one functional protein, the spatial relationship between the polypeptide subunits is referred to as quaternary structure.

Bonds involved in Tertiary and Quaternary Structures are primarily noncovalent bonds.

  • Hydrophobic Interaction
  • Hydrogen Bond
  • Electrostatic Bond
  • Vander Waal’s Forces

Reference: Harper 30/e p39

questions.text: Glycogen is released from the muscle due to increased cAMP due to:
questions.solution:
Difference between muscle and Liver In regulation of Glycogen Metabolism

  • Epinephrine acts in Muscle and Liver whereas Glucagon acts only in the Liver
  • In the muscle there is cAMP-independent activation of glycogenolysis by the stimulation of a Ca2+/calmodulin-sensitive phosphorylase kinase
  • Glycogen Phosphorylase in the muscle Favor glycogenolysis
  • Muscle phosphorylase can be activated without phosphorylation
  • Muscle Phosphorylase has a binding site for 5’AMP
  • 5’AMP is an allosteric activator without phosphorylation
  • Favor
  • In the liver, the role of glycogen is to provide free glucose for export to maintain the blood concentration of glucose; in muscle, the role of glycogen is to provide a source of glucose-6-phosphate for glycolysis in response to the need for ATP for muscle contraction.
  • In both tissues, the enzyme is activated by phosphorylation catalyzed by phosphorylase kinase (to yield phosphorylase a) and inactivated by dephosphorylation catalyzed by phosphoprotein phosphatase (to yield phosphorylase b), in response to hormonal and other signals.
  • There is instantaneous overriding of this hormonal control.
  • Active phosphorylase a in both tissues is allosterically inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate; in liver, but not muscle, free glucose is also an inhibitor.
  • Muscle phosphorylase differs from the liver isoenzyme in having a binding site for 5′ AMP , which acts as an allosteric activator of the (inactive) dephosphorylated b-form of the enzyme.

Reference: Harper 31/e p422

questions.text: Which of the following is not a features of genetic code?
questions.solution:
The characteristics of the genetic code are:

Option A: Unambiguous or Specificity: A particular codon always codes for same amino acid. It is not ambiguous.

Option B: Degeneracy: The genetic code is degenerate (sometimes called redundant). Although each codon corresponds to a single amino acid, a given amino acid may have more than one triplet coding for it. For example, arginine (Arg) is specified by six different codons Only Methionine (Met) and Tryptophan (Trp) have just one coding triplet.

Option C & D: Nonoverlapping and Non punctuated: The genetic code is nonoverlapping and commaless, meaning that the code is read from a fixed starting point as a continuous sequence of bases, taken three at a time without any punctuation between codons (commaless). For example, AGCUGGAUACAU is read as AGC UGG AUA CAU.

Genetic code

Genetic information, stored in the chromosomes and transmitted to daughter cells

through DNA replication. But it is expressed through transcription to mRNA (messenger RNA), subsequent translation into proteins (polypeptide chains) with help of tRNA (transfer RNA). During translation the language of the nucleotide sequence on the mRNA is translated into the language of an amino acid sequence. Translation requires a genetic code, through which the information contained in the nucleic acid sequence is expressed to produce a specific sequence of amino acids. Any alteration in the nucleic acid sequence may result in an incorrect amino acid being inserted into the polypeptide chain, potentially causing disease or even death of the organism.

Genetic code determines which amino acids are coded for by an mRNA. Codons are presented in mRNA language of four nucleotides (adenine (A), guanine (G), cytosine (C) and uracil (U)). The four nucleotide bases are used to produce the three-base codons. So 64 different combinations of bases, taken three at a time (a triplet code).


The genetic code is virtually universal. An exception occurs in mitochondria, in which a few codons have meanings different than those shown in table.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 395

choices.text: Add non-vegetarian food in diet to fulfil nutritional requirement of body

questions.text:
A 51-year old male executive after completing his business visit, next day morning presented with following clinical features showing in images.

His uric acid level is 11.5 mg/dl (normal 3.5 to 7 mg/dl). He was diagnosed to have acute gout. All the following non pharmacological measure will be advised in management of this patient to prevent such attack, except:
questions.solution:
Option A: Alkalization of urine increase solubility of uric acid, so more uric acid is excreted

Option B: Adequate hydration also help to solubilize and excrete uric acid, so advised to drink plenty of water.

Option C: Non vegetarian food should be avoided, as it contains high quantity of purines which further breakdown and produces more uric acid, and leads to gout.

Option D: Alcohol reduces excretion of uric acid, so increase uric acid level and precipitate gout.

Reference: Textbook of Medical Biochemistry by MN Chatterjea & Rana Shinde, 8th edition, PN 235

questions.text: In mammals the end product of purine catabolism is allantoin. But in human an end product of purine catabolism is uric acid because human lack enzyme:
questions.solution:
Option A: Uricase enzyme convert uric acid into allantoin. Allantoin is more water soluble than uric acid. But in human uricase enzyme is absent, so end product of purine catabolism is uric acid. Uricase is present into mammals, so they convert uric acid into allantoin.

Option B: Xanthine oxidase enzyme convert Hypoxanthine into Xanthine and Xanthine into Uric acid. This enzyme presents in mammals and human both, so both breakdown purines up to uric acid.

Option C: HGPRTase is an enzyme involved in salvage pathway. It converts Guanine & Hypoxanthine into GMP & IMP.

Option D: PRPP synthase is enzyme involved in denovo synthesis of purine

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 334

questions.text: Salvage pathway is very important for following organs to meet their need for purine nucleotide except:
questions.solution:
Option A: Liver is the major site of purine nucleotide biosynthesis, even liver provides purines and purine nucleosides for salvage and for utilization by tissues incapable of their biosynthesis.

Option B: Human brain tissue has a low level of PRPP glutamyl amidotransfer­ase, an enzyme involved in denovo purine biosynthesis and hence depends in part on exogenous purines.

Option C & D: Erythrocytes and polymorpho­nuclear leukocytes cannot synthesize 5-phosphoribosylamine, so denovo synthesis cannot proceed further and therefore also utilize exog­enous purines to form nucleotides.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 330

choices.text: Convert into uric acid and excreted in urine
Convert into allantoin and excreted in urine
Convert into beta amino isobutyrate & excreted in urine

questions.text: Pseudouridine is an unusual nucleotide found in transfer RNA. During degradation of transfer RNA, pseudouridine is excreted in urine by which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
Option A: All purine N base when catabolised, it converts into uric acid and excreted in urine. But pseudouridine is not a purine N base.

Option B: In mammals, enzyme Uricase further convert uric acid into allantoin, then allantoin excreted in urine in mammals during purine catabolism. But in human uricase enzyme is absent, so end product of purine catabolism is uric acid, and uric acid excreted in urine. But pseudouridine is not a purine N base.

Option C: During pyrimidine catabolism, end product will be beta amino isobutyrate or beta alanine & then beta amino isobutyrate is excreted in urine. Pseudouridine is unusual pyrimidine nucleotide but it will not convert into beta amino isobutyrate or beta alanine. It is an exception.

Option D: No human enzyme catalyzes hydrolysis or phosphorolysis of the pseudouridine (ψ). This unusual nucleotide therefore is excreted unchanged in the urine of normal subjects.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 336

questions.text: A sequence of codon 6 of the beta chain changed from GAG in normal gene to GTG in sickle cell gene, which in turn result in A to U changes in mRNA. Such mutation resulting in substitution of valine for glutamic acid in beta globin polypeptide chain during Hb synthesis. All the following techniques can be used to detect such mutation in RBC sample taken from sickle cell anemia patient, except:
questions.solution:
Option A: Point mutations are usually detected by sequencing the gene in question.

Option B: PCR-based assays can detect much smaller changes or mutation in DNA structure.

Option C: The technique of restriction fragment analysis can be used to pinpoint such mutation, if the mutation destroys or creates a restriction enzyme site,

Option D: Western blotting technique used to detect any change in protein sequence not in DNA. Deletions or insertions of DNA larger than 50 bp can often be detected by the Southern blotting procedure.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 443

questions.text: If more than one codon code for same amino acid, such phenomenon called as
questions.solution:
Option A: A same amino acid may have more than one codon for it, termed as Degeneracy

Option B: A particular codon always codes for one amino acid, termed as Unambiguous or Specificity

Option C: A particular codon always codes for more than one amino acid, termed as ambiguous for example, arginine (Arg) is specified by six different codons Only Methionine (Met) and Tryptophan (Trp) have just one coding triplet.

Option D: A code is read from a fixed starting point as a continuous sequence of bases, taken three at a time without any punctuation between codons For example, AGCUGGAUACAU is read as AGC UGG AUA CAU.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 395

questions.text: Major sources of ~ Phosphate taking part in energy conservation or energy capture are all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Option A: Oxidative phosphorylation is the greatest quantitative source of ~ phosphate in aerobic organisms. Finally, all reduced coenzymes like NADH2 or FADH2 undergoes ETC and generate ATP by oxidative phosphorylation. ATP is generated in the mitochondrial matrix as O2 is reduced to H2O by electrons passing down the respiratory chain.

Option B: Glycolysis: A net formation of two ~ phosphate results when one molecule of glucose breaks down into pyruvate (in aerobic condition) or lactate (in anaerobic condition). They are generated in two reactions catalyzed by phosphoglyc­erate kinase and pyruvate kinase, respectively (examples of substrate level phosphorylation). Anaerobic glycolysis is the only source of ~ phosphate production in absence of oxygen.

Option C: Citric acid cycle: One ~ phosphate is generated directly in TCA cycle at the succinate thiokinase step (also an examples of substrate level phosphorylation).

Option D: Beta oxidation of fatty acid: used to breakdown of palmitic acid or stearic acid in body. But this pathway will not produce ~ phosphate directly at substrate level. Instead it produces reduced coenzymes like NADH2 or FADH2 undergoes ETC and generate ATP by oxidative phosphorylation. A breakdown of one molecule of palmitic acid (16C, saturated fatty acid) produces net 106 ATP and breakdown of one molecule of stearic acid (18C, saturated fatty acid) produce 120 ATPs.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 108

questions.text: All of the following complexes in electron transport chain act as proton pump, except:
questions.solution:
The chemiosmotic theory of oxidative phosphorylation:

Complexes I, III, and IV (Option A, C, D) act as proton pumps creating a proton gradient across the membrane, which is negative on the matrix side. The proton motive force generated drives the synthesis of ATP as the pro­tons flow back into the matrix through the ATP synthase enzyme.

Complex II (Option B) not act as proton pump.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 122

questions.text: In biological oxidation, the electron is flowing from reduced coenzyme like NADH2 or FADH2, which is associated with generation of proton gradient and finally end up in production of ATP. All these process are link together, which are explained by following theory:
questions.solution:
Electron when passes through various complexes in electron transport chain, then complex I, III and IV act as proton pumps creating a proton gradient across the membrane, which is negative on the matrix side. The proton motive force generated drives the synthesis of ATP as the pro­tons flow back into the matrix through the ATP synthase enzyme. This is known as chemiosmotic theory of oxidative phosphorylation.

Option A, B, D: In oxidative phosphorylation, electron flow, generation of proton gradient and ATP production are not explained by any chemical, physical or conformational theory.

Chemiosmotic theory

  • Transport of electrons through electron transport chain is accompanied by generation of a proton gradient across membrane.
  • Protons accumulate outside the inner membrane (inside the inter membranous space) creating an electrochemical potential difference across inner mitochondrial membrane
  • This proton force drives the synthesis of ATP by ATP synthase complex.
  • This phenomenon is known as Chemiosmotic theory.


Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 122

choices.text: Inhibit oxidative phosphorylation by inhibiting the transporter of ADP into and ATP out of the mitochondrion

questions.text: Which of the following is mechanism of action of Atractyloside?
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of respiratory chain provided knowledge about the mechanism of action of several poisons. They may be classified as inhibitors of the respiratory chain, inhibitors of oxidative phosphorylation, or uncouplers of oxidative phosphorylation.

Option A: Inhibitors of ETC or respiratory chain

Barbiturates such as amobarbital inhibit electron trans­port via Complex I.

Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of Complex II.

Antimycin A and dimer­caprol inhibit the respiratory chain at Complex III.

H2S, carbon monoxide, and cyanide inhibit Complex IV.

Option B: Cytochrome oxidase is complex IV of ETC. Inhibitor of cytochrome oxidase are H2S, carbon monoxide, and cyanide.

Option C: Uncouplers dissociate oxidation in the respiratory chain from phosphorylation. The uncoupler that has been used most frequently is 2,4- dinitrophenol.

Thermogenin is a physiologic uncoupler found in brown adipose tissue that functions to generate body heat, particularly for the newborn and during hibernation in animals.

Option D: Atractyloside inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by inhibiting the transporter of ADP into and ATP out of the mitochondrion.



The antibiotic oligomycin also completely blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by blocking the flow of protons through ATP synthase.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 132

questions.text: All of the following are physiological Uncouplers except:
questions.solution:
2,4- dinitrophenol (Option A) is chemical uncoupler, whereas Thermogenin, Bilirubin and Free fatty acids (Option B, C, D) are physiological uncouplers.

Uncouplers dissociate oxidation in the respiratory chain from phosphorylation. They may be chemical or physiological uncouplers:

Chemical Uncouplers are:

The uncoupler that has been used most frequently is 2,4- dinitrophenol. Other chemical uncouplers are dicumarol (anticoagulant), CCCP (chlorocarbonylcyanide phenylhydrazone), salicylate (metabolite of aspirin)

Physiological Uncouplers are:

Thermogenin is a physiologic uncoupler found in brown adipose tissue that functions to generate body heat, particularly for the newborn and during hibernation in animals.

Some other physiological uncoupler are thyroxine, bilirubin and free fatty acids. But these compounds normally not present in concentration high enough to act as uncouplers.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 132

questions.text: During the course of evolution, the ability to synthesize vitamins was lost in higher organisms, so they have to obtain all vitamin from diet except
questions.solution:
Higher organisms have to obtain all vitamins from diet, because during the course of evolution, the ability to synthesize vitamins was lost. Two exception to this rule:

  • vitamin D (calcitriol), which is formed in the skin from 7-dehydrocholesterol on exposure to sun­light,
  • Niacin (sometime termed as vitamin B3), which can be formed from the essential amino acid tryptophan, do not strictly comply with this definition.

Option A: Calcitriol can be synthesized from 7 dehydro cholesterol in skin & Niacin can be synthesized from tryptophan

Option B: Retinol cannot be produced in body, only Calcitriol can be synthesized from 7 dehydro cholesterol

Option C: Niacin can be synthesized from tryptophan, but thiamine has to obtained from diet as it cannot be synthesized

Option D: Niacin can be synthesized from tryptophan, but folic acid has to obtained from diet as it cannot be synthesized

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 528

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presented to physician with complaints of bruises, petechiae, excessive menstrual bleeding. Then routine hemogram and bone marrow biopsy was done. She was diagnosed having acute promyelocytic leukemia. Which of the following vitamin A compound has a role in regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation and used in treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: 11 cis retinal has role in vision, no role in regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation

Option B: 11 trans retinal also involved in visual cycle, no role in regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation

Option C: Trans retinoic acid has role in regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation, so commonly used as drug in treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

All-trans-retinoic acid and 9-cis-retinoic acid regulate growth, development, and tissue differentiation; they have different actions in different tis­sues. Like the thyroid and steroid hormones and vitamin D, retinoic acid binds to nuclear receptors that bind to response elements of DNA and regulate the transcription of specific genes.

Option D: beta carotene has antioxidant action, but no role in regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 529

questions.text: Vitamin D is not strictly a vitamin but it is really a hormone because all of the following feature are similar to hormone except:
questions.solution:
Option A: Vitamin D can be synthesized in skin from7 dehydrocholesterol with help of sunlight like hormones which are produced by different endocrine organs

Option B: Vitamin D Regulate calcium homeostasis along with parathyroid hormone (PTH) and calcitonin

Option C: Vitamin D act on target cell via nuclear receptor that regulate gene expres­sion. like thyroid and steroid hormone. It also has a role in regulating cell proliferation and dif­ferentiation.

Option D: Usually hormone will not be taken in diet. But when sunlight exposure is inadequate is a dietary source required for vitamin D

Vitamin D is considered as Hormone

Due to Similar characteristics like hormone

  1. Structurally similar to steroid hormone (have steroid ring)
  2. Synthesized in skin by UV rays (Provit D to Vit D)
  3. Further activated in liver and kidney to form active form (cholecalciferol to Calcidiol to Calcitriol)
  4. Subject to feedback inhibition
  5. Molecular mechanism of action is similar to steroid hormone (Binds to Vitamin D Receptor in nucleus to up regulate gene expression in target cells)
  6. Definite target organ to act (Bone, intestine & Kidney)
  7. Maintain Ca homeostasis along with PTH & Calcitonin

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 530

questions.text: Major lipid soluble antioxidant found in cell membranes is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Beta carotene is provitamin A, having antioxidant activity, but not found in major amount in cell membrane

Option B: Vitamin D doesn’t not have any anti-oxidant activity

Option C: Vitamin E is a major lipid soluble anti oxidant found in cell membrane

Option D: Vitamin C is water soluble vitamin, termed as ascorbic acid, have anti oxidant property

Vitamin E Is the Major Lipid-Soluble Antioxidant in Cell Membranes & Plasma Lipoproteins

The main function of vitamin E is as a chain-breaking, free radical–trapping antioxidant in cell membranes and plasma lipoproteins by reacting with the lipid peroxide radicals formed by peroxidation of polyunsaturated fatty acids. The tocopheroxyl radical is relatively unreactive, and ultimately forms nonradical compounds. Commonly, the tocopheroxyl radical is reduced back to tocopherol by reaction with vitamin C from plasma. The resultant, stable, monodehy­droascorbate radical then undergoes enzymic or nonenzymic reaction to yield ascorbate and dehydroascorbate, neither of which is a radical.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 532

questions.text: Vitamin D deficiency leads to demineralization of bone in adult, which can lead to:
questions.solution:
Option A: Scurvy occurs due to deficiency of vitamin C. In scurvy collagen tissue synthesis in bone are mainly affected, which lead to scorbutic bone, along with bleeding gums, haemorrhages, petechial etc

Option B: Rickets occurs due to deficiency of vitamin D in growing children. Here demineralization of bone occurs which can lead to various deformities like bowed leg, knock knee, pigeon chest etc

Option C: Osteoporosis is demineralization of bone occurs mainly due to calcium deficiency. There is less evidence that vitamin D supplementation is beneficial in treating osteoporosis.

Option D: Osteomalacia occurs due to vitamin D deficiency in adult. Osteomalacia in adults results from the demineralization of bone, especially in women who have little exposure to sunlight, especially after several preg­nancies. Vitamin D is essential for prevention and treatment of osteomalacia in the elderly.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 532

questions.text: All of the following clotting factor requires vitamin K for activation except
questions.solution:
Option A: Fibrinogen do not require vitamin K for their activity

Option B, C, D: Prothrombin, Protein C, Protein S require vitamin K for their activity.

Activation of prothrombin, factors VII, IX, and X, and proteins C and S of the blood-clotting system require gamma Carboxylation of Glutamate residues. Vitamin K Is the Coenzyme for Carboxylation of Glutamate in Postsynthetic Modification. All such proteins contain 4 to 6 γ-carboxyglutamate residues. γ-Carboxyglutamate chelates calcium ions, and so permits the binding of the blood-clotting proteins to membranes and help in blood clotting.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 533

questions.text: How much tryptophan is equivalent to 1 mg of dietary niacin?
questions.solution:
Some 60 mg of tryptophan is equivalent to 1 mg of dietary niacin.

The niacin content of foods is expressed as:

mg niacin equivalents = mg preformed niacin + 1/60 × mg tryptophan

So only option B is correct, other option A, C, D are incorrect.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 534

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity is assayed in Erythrocyte to assess Vitamin B6 Status?
questions.solution:
Option A & B: Transaldolase & Transketolase enzymes are involved in HMP shunt pathway, they do not require vitamin B6 as coenzyme.

Thiamine Nutritional Status Can Be Assessed by addition of thiamine diphosphate in vitro in erythrocyte lysate to assess activity of transketolase.

Option C: Vitamin B6 status is assessed by assaying erythrocyte transaminases. The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro, expressed as the activation coeffi­cient. Measurement of plasma concentrations of the vitamin is also used.

Option D: Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in HMP shunt, but it doesn’t require vitamin B6 as coenzyme.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 535

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency lead to clinical picture showing in following image of new born child?
questions.solution:
Clinical feature seen in above image is spina bifida (neural tube defect), which occurs due to deficiency of folic acid during pregnancy.

Supplements of folic acid during pregnancy or even before concep­tion result in a significant reduction in the incidence of spina bifida and other neural tube defects.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 538

questions.text: All of the following are involved in membrane function, except:
questions.solution:
Sodium, potassium and chloride (Option A, B, C) are considered electrolyte which help to maintain membrane potential. Magnesium (Option D) has no role in membrane function.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 540

choices.text: Glycemic index of non-starch like cellulose is 0
Foods that have a low glycemic index are considered to be more beneficial since they cause less fluctuation in insulin secretion
Foods that have a high glycemic index are considered to be more beneficial since they cause less fluctuation in insulin secretion

questions.text: The increase in blood glucose after a test dose of a carbohydrate compared with that after an equivalent amount of glucose is known as the glycemic index. All of the following sentences is true regarding Glycemic index, except:
questions.solution:
Option A & Option B:

Glucose and galactose also have an index of 1 (or 100%), as do lactose, maltose, isomaltose, and trehalose, which give rise to these monosaccharides on hydro­lysis.

Fructose and the sugar alcohols are absorbed less rapidly and have a lower glycemic index, as does sucrose. The glyce­mic index of starch varies between near 1 (or 100%) and near 0 as a result of variable rates of hydrolysis, and that of nonstarch polysaccharides like cellulose is 0 as it is not digested in human intestine.

Option C: Foods that have a low glycemic index are considered to be more beneficial since they cause less fluctuation in insulin secretion.

Option D: Foods that have a high glycemic index are considered to be harmful in diabetic patients as it will raise blood sugar level much and impair sugar control in diabetic patients.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 520
